div1.p: Gorgas asks Wood to write the preface to the biography she is writing about her husband. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from Marie D. Gorgas to Leonard Wood, February 6, 1922 [Enclosed in KAFL0010]
div1.opener:
The Highlands,
Washington, D.C., February 6, 1922
My dear General Wood:
div1.p:
You and Dr. Gorgas were so intimately associated in Havana
- so much of his success was due to your confidence and belief in him,
and in his ability, that I intended to ask you to write the preface to
his biography which I am writing.

Your letter however which Colonel Clarke gave me not only
refutes the misleading statements made by General Goethals, but will
answer too I think for the preface. It is a splendid tribute, remarkably
well expressed.

I am very grateful, and know that your letter will add
greatly to the value of my book, which would not be complete without
a word from you.

Doubleday, Page and Company have the contract. The book
will probably not come out until fall, although certain chapters may
be published in serial form in connection with the “Gorgas Memorial.”

You are such a busy man and have constant demands on your
time, so I hesitate to ask you to write anything more. But if any lit-
tle items of the Havana days occur to you, do jot them down and send me.
Dr. Gorgas always said that you made him. Does that carry any respon-
sibility?
With love to Mrs. Wood and best wishes for a happy New Year,
div1.closer: Very sincerely yours, (Sgd.) MARIA D. GORGAS February the sixth.
